questions.question_text:
An administrator created a new cost-based pricing card and attached it to a VMware Cloud on AWS (VMC) resource. When the administrator checked the pricing of a VM after the cost calculation had successfully run, the pricing showed zero.

What is the possible reason for this situation?

choices.C: The cost calculation needs to run twice, when using VMC.
choices.B: Only rate-based pricing cards are applied with VMC.
choices.A: A zero value was used for one of the Basic Charges in the pricing card.
choices.D: Pricing cards are not supported with VMC resources.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
VMC only supports rate-based pricing cards

choices.B: The allocation model does not account for powered off virtual machines.
choices.A: The allocation model will always report zero remaining capacity when the actual ratio is less than the configured ratio.
choices.D: The CPU demand in the cluster is greater than the total CPU capacity.
choices.C: The CPU demand in the cluster is less than the total CPU capacity.

questions.question_text:
An administrator has enabled the allocation model in a policy and set the CPU overcommit ratio to 4:1 for all vSphere clusters in a vSphere datacenter.
Why would vRealize Operations report that the cluster has 0 days remaining when the actual CPU overcommit ratio is less than the 4:1 configured value?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
For me The CPU demand in the cluster is greater than the total CPU capacity

questions.question_text:
A system administrator has been assigned a task to create a capacity policy with the following requirements:

â€¢ ESXi clusters under custom group "Database Servers" requires a CPU allocation model with overcommit ratio of 2:1

All ESXi clusters in the environment at the moment has been assigned with capacity policy for CPU allocation model with overcommit ratio of 4:1.

Which three actions should be performed to ensure that the above capacity policy is correctly applied? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABC
BCA.

B. Create a new policy "Database Servers", and then inherit it from Base Settings.
C. Edit the new policy under section Groups and Objects, and then select Custom Group "Database Servers".
A. Edit the new policy under section Capacity, filter object type by custom group "Database Servers", and then modify Allocation model to 2:1.
These steps will ensure that the new policy is created, associated with the correct custom group, and configured with the desired CPU allocation model
